dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, I mean, can we even keep up with Brexit anymore? Boris Johnson, like, totally defied expectations, right? He announced he's accelerating the deadline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, I mean, can we even keep up with Brexit anymore? Boris Johnson, like, totally defied expectations, right? He announced he's accelerating the deadline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit, meaning the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and here's the wild part, Host_A. The EU leaders, surprisingly, they just flat out voted to deny the UK any further extension. No 'flextension' for them, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and here's the wild part, Host_A. The E U leaders, surprisingly, they just flat out voted to deny the U K any further extension. No flextension for them, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Right? And, um, Donald Tusk, the EU Council president, he basically cemented it. Said the EU27 rejected the request, and the January 31st deadline, that's it. It's enforced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And, um, Donald Tusk, the E U Council president, he basically cemented it. Said the E U twenty seven rejected the request, and the January thirty first deadline, that's it. It's enforced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU Council president Donald Tusk tweeted the confirmation on Monday. He said: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which means, I mean, they *have* to leave before January 31st, even if both parliaments, uh, fail to ratify a deal. It's just... done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means, I mean, they have to leave before January thirty first, even if both parliaments, uh, fail to ratify a deal. It's just... done.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The flextension means that the U.K. would be allowed to leave the EU before January 31, if the British and European Parliaments ratifiy a deal before then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And this dramatic shift, it came *after* Johnson actually managed to pass his Brexit bill, twice even!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And this dramatic shift, it came after Johnson actually managed to pass his Brexit bill, twice even!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension, after a vote on his Brexit bill was blocked, twice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and now, he's just abandoned any plans for a general election. Like, they're celebrating the deal's immediate effect this afternoon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and now, he's just abandoned any plans for a general election. Like, they're celebrating the deal's immediate effect this afternoon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move now means Johnson will push for a general election this December, with British lawmakers set to debate the move this afternoon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, but isn't it, like, super ironic? Because Johnson was the one who always advocated for a flexible approach, right? He even delayed the UK's exit beyond October 31st before!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, but isn't it, like, super ironic? Because Johnson was the one who always advocated for a flexible approach, right? He even delayed the U K's exit beyond October thirty first before!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson has previously said he would rather be dead in a ditch than to further delay Topline: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit, meaning the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. He was hailed for, uh, his "negotiation success" securing a deal, which then, *immediately*, UK parliamentarians rejected it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. He was hailed for, uh, his negotiation success securing a deal, which then, immediately, U K parliamentarians rejected it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which sets out the terms of the U.K.s exit from the EU.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, last week, they voted down his Withdrawal Agreement Bill, the WAB, that set out the terms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, last week, they voted down his Withdrawal Agreement Bill, the W A B, that set out the terms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which sets out the terms of the U.K.s exit from the EU.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And then Johnson, uh, he immediately pushed the deal forward *again*! He got them to grant an extra three-day window to debate it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Johnson, uh, he immediately pushed the deal forward again! He got them to grant an extra three-day window to debate it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson then paused the deal after lawmakers rejected a short three-day window in which to debate it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which you'd think would be a good thing, right? Like, more debate. But then, *contrary to expectations*, Johnson announced Friday he's *not* allowing lawmakers to debate it!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which you'd think would be a good thing, right? Like, more debate. But then, contrary to expectations, Johnson announced Friday he's not allowing lawmakers to debate it!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for the bill to progress further, Johnson said on Friday that he would allow lawmakers to debate it if they agreed to allowing an election on December 12.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, he's just, like, cutting it off. Regardless of their preference to have an election on December 12th. It's just... done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, he's just, like, cutting it off. Regardless of their preference to have an election on December twelfth. It's just... done.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for the bill to progress further, Johnson said on Friday that he would allow lawmakers to debate it if they agreed to allowing an election on December 12.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, basically, we went from "flextension possible" to "no flextension," to "deal passed," to "deal rejected," to "deal pushed again," to "no debate, it's happening."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, basically, we went from flextension possible to no flextension, to deal passed, to deal rejected, to deal pushed again, to no debate, it's happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020. The flextension means that the U.K. would be allowed to leave the EU before January 31, if the British and European Parliaments ratifiy a deal before then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. I mean, if you're looking for consistency, you're definitely not gonna find it, uh, in this Brexit saga, are you?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. I mean, if you're looking for consistency, you're definitely not gonna find it, uh, in this Brexit saga, are you?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely not. It's a rollercoaster every single day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely not. It's a rollercoaster every single day.
